header.title: THE SECRET HISTORY OF MODERN WITCHCRAFT
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Modern Witchcraft, Thelema, OTO History

central_thesis: The central thesis is that modern Wicca, particularly Gardnerian Wicca, is not an ancient, lineal tradition but a 20th-century creation, largely 'invented' or popularized by Gerald Gardner, and heavily influenced by Aleister Crowley and his Ordo Templi Orientis (OTO). The author posits Wicca as a populist adaptation of Crowley's Thelemic magical religion, incorporating elements from his Gnostic Mass and emphasizing sexual magick.

structure_content.summary: The author introduces the topic with quotes from occult figures and a skeptical historical perspective on witchcraft. He details his personal involvement with OTO and Neopagan groups, the evolution of his essay, and the new evidence used in this revision regarding Gardner's OTO status and the Book of Shadows.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Dream: A Fictionalized Origin of Wicca
structure_content.summary: A vivid, fictionalized dream depicts Aleister Crowley and Gerald Gardner in 1945 discussing the creation of a popular cult, integrating OTO elements (like the Book of the Law and Gnostic Mass) with 'razzle-dazzle' for the masses, including an emphasis on naked rituals and sexual magic. This dream serves as a metaphorical representation of the author's theory of Wicca's origins.

structure_content.chapter_title: Defining Modern Witchcraft and Its Mythology
structure_content.summary: Greenfield distinguishes between popular concepts of 'witchcraft' and modern Wicca. He critically examines Wiccan claims of 'apostolic succession' and lineal descent from ancient, prehistoric religions, arguing that such historical narratives are often mythological constructs rather than factual accounts, drawing a parallel to how mythologies are formed.

The author analyzes historical witch trials (roughly 1484-1692), concluding that the widespread 'witch mania' was a delusion perpetuated by Christian clergymen and authorities, relying on torture-induced confessions. He argues against the idea that these trials provide evidence for a surviving pagan religious cult or any form of witchcraft resembling modern Wicca, contrasting with views like Dr. Margaret Murray's.

structure_content.chapter_title: Modern Wicca's Influences and Early Figures
structure_content.summary: Greenfield explores the components that fed into modern Wicca, acknowledging the survival of folk magic and ceremonial magic. He questions if Wicca existed as a coherent creed before the 1940s and the interaction between Crowley and Gardner, touching upon figures like George Pickingill and observations from Doreen Valiente.

structure_content.chapter_title: Crowley, Gardner, and the Nature of Their Magic
structure_content.summary: The author highlights Crowley and Gardner's shared belief in 'fleshly fulfillment' and sexual magick as paths to spiritual attainment. He contrasts Gardnerian Wicca's original, libertine nature with later 'Neopuritan' and feminist revisions, portraying both men as 'spiritual libertines' and popularizers of an operative magical system that engaged with human sexuality.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Charter and The Book: Gardner's OTO Link and the Book of Shadows
structure_content.summary: This section details the author's discovery and analysis of Gerald Gardner's OTO Charter, signed by Aleister Crowley around 1945, which authorized Gardner to establish an OTO encampment and initiate members. He discusses Gardner's claims of OTO leadership in Europe and the contentious origins of the 'Book of Shadows,' including the different versions (Texts A, B, C) and their direct connections to Crowley's writings.

Greenfield clarifies the distinction between Wicca and Satanism, defining the latter as 'reverse Christianity' and emphasizing that occultists (including Crowley) use 'Satanic' symbolism theatrically, not as literal devil worship. He discusses the historical and psychological roots of such 'counter-Christianity' and groups like Anton LaVey's Church of Satan.

The author reiterates that Wicca began as an OTO encampment, citing Jack Parsons' 1946 writings forecasting a revival of witchcraft, Crowley's ongoing optimistic references to Gardner's OTO work, and Gardner's own claims of OTO leadership in Europe post-Crowley. He suggests a direct lineage from Crowley's Thelema to Gardnerian Wicca.

structure_content.chapter_title: Examination of 'Ye Book of Ye Art Magical'
structure_content.summary: Greenfield recounts his discovery of 'Ye Book of Ye Art Magical,' identified as Gardner's original compilation for the Book of Shadows. He describes its physical appearance (an old, rebound notebook) and the handwriting (Gerald Gardner's), noting that its content is largely derived from Crowley's published works, suggesting it was a developmental outline rather than an ancient text.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Real Origin of Wicca and Its Modern Transformations
structure_content.summary: The author concludes that the 'ancient' legend of Wicca is false, asserting its modern origin in Crowley's Thelema, Gnostic Mass, and Freemasonry. He critiques subsequent 'watering down' into 'mushy white-light' and 'radical feminist' versions, arguing these deviate from the original 'pansexualism' and 'balance' understood by Crowley and Gardner.

key_concepts.definition: A contemporary spiritual movement, often claimed to be ancient, but analyzed by the author as a mid-20th-century invention or popularization rooted in other esoteric traditions.
A Thelemic magical order, founded by Aleister Crowley, which the author identifies as the direct precursor and primary influence for the practical and philosophical foundation of Gardnerian Wicca.

A prominent 20th-century occultist and Magus, founder of Thelema, whose published works and philosophical system are presented as the essential source material for the rituals and core ideas of early Wicca.
Regarded as the popularizer or 'inventor' of modern Wicca, who received an OTO charter from Crowley and adapted Crowley's Thelemic teachings into the structure and practices of his new witch cult.

The central ritual text of Wicca, which the author argues is not an ancient document but a compilation, largely in Gardner's handwriting, dating from the mid-20th century and heavily influenced by Crowley and OTO materials.

A ritual written by Aleister Crowley (Liber XV), explicitly identified by the author as the direct source and template for the Wiccan Third Degree initiation, particularly its 'nonsymbolic' (sexual) Great Rite.

Aleister Crowley's philosophical and religious system, based on the 'Book of the Law,' which emphasizes the principle of 'Do what thou wilt' and is presented as the underlying current for Gardnerian Wicca.

Described as 'reverse Christianity' rather than an ancient pagan religion, distinct from Wicca. Crowley's use of Satanic symbolism is characterized as theatrical and ironic, not indicative of literal devil worship.

key_concepts.term: Ye Book of Ye Art Magical
key_concepts.definition: A specific notebook discovered by the author, identified as Gerald Gardner's original working draft or outline for the Book of Shadows, which contains extensive material derived from Crowley's writings.
The claim by some Wiccans of a direct, lineal transmission of knowledge and ordination from ancient pagan traditions, a claim the author disputes by presenting evidence of Wicca's modern origins.

practical_system.description: According to the author's analysis, the practical system of early Gardnerian Wicca was conceived as a popularized adaptation of Aleister Crowley's Thelemic magical system, specifically the OTO. It aimed to make esoteric practices accessible to a broader audience, emphasizing 'fleshly fulfillment' and sexual magick as integral components for spiritual attainment. The Third Degree initiation, in particular, is presented as directly derived from Crowley's 'nonsymbolic' Gnostic Mass, indicating an operative focus on direct experience and transformation rather than solely symbolic or theoretical engagement. The system incorporated elements of ceremonial magic and folk magic, modified for a new 'witch cult.'
tools: The Book of Shadows (as a compendium of rituals and teachings)
OTO Charter (as official authorization for founding a magical group or 'encampment')
Ritual implements (e.g., a sword with a cruciform brass hilt, implied for ceremonial and 'Great Rite' practices)
rituals: Wiccan Third Degree Initiation (derived from Crowley's Gnostic Mass, incorporating the 'nonsymbolic Great Rite')
Initiation rituals (adapted from crypto-Freemasonic rituals, Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn, OTO, and NeoRosicrucian groups)
Elemental rituals (part of the Book of Shadows content)
The Gnostic Mass (Crowley's original Liber XV, serving as a template for Wiccan rites)

relevant_quotes.text: "The fact is that the instincts of ignorant people invariably find expression in some form of witchcraft. It matters little what the metaphysician or the moralist may inculcate; the animal sticks to his subconscious ideas..." Aleister Crowley The Confessions

[This monograph has a long history. ... The present revision includes new insights into the early claims concerning Gerald Gardner relative to his status in the OTO. ... It is of more than passing interest that Ye Book of Ye Arte Magical, the OTO Charter granted to Gerald Gardner by Aleister Crowley, the writings by Parsons on witchcraft, the publication of High Magic's Aid and the public emergence of Wicca all date from the same period, circa 1945-1950.]

Great story, but merely a dream, created out of bits and pieces of rumor, history and imagination. Don't be surprised, though, if a year or five years from now you read it as "gospel" (which an ironic synonym for 'truth') in some new learned text on the fabled history of Wicca. Such is the way all mythologies come into being.

Stated in its most extreme form, Wicca may be defined as an ancient pagan religious system of beliefs and practices, with a form of `apostolic' succession (that is, with knowledge and ordination handed on linearly from generation to generation), a more or less consistent set of rites and myths, and even a secret holy book of considerable antiquity (The Book of Shadows).

But, to an extent, this misses the point and skirts an essential question anyone has the right to ask about modern Wicca -- namely, did Wicca exist as a coherent creed, a distinct form of spiritual expression, prior to the 1940s; that is, prior to the meeting of minds between the old magus and venerable prophet of the occult world Aleister Crowley, and the first popularizer, if not outright inventor of modern Wicca, Gerald Brosseau Gardner?

Crowley very much lacked the common touch; Gardner was above all things a popularizer. Both men have been reviled as lecherous "dirty old men" -- Crowley, as a seducer of women and a homosexual, a drug addict and `Satanist' rolled together. Gardner was, they would have it, a voyeur, exhibitionist and bondage freak with a `penchant for ritual' to borrow a line from THE STORY OF O. Both were, in reality, spiritual libertines, ceremonial magicians who did not shy away from the awesome force of human sexuality and its potential for spiritual transformation as well as physical gratification.

I do know that, around 1945, Crowley met with Gardner, and gave him license to organize an OTO encampment. This was, as it turns out, a serious effort by Crowley to establish a new OTO presence in Britain.

The claim is frequently made by those who wish to`salvage' a preGardnerian source of Wiccan materials that there is a `core' of `authentic' materials. But, as the Farrars' recently asserted, the portions of the Book of Shadows "..which changed least between Texts A, B and C were naturally the three initiation rituals; because these, above all, would be the traditional elements which would have been carefully preserved, probably for centuries...."

The Third Degree ritual, perhaps Wicca's ultimate rite, is, essentially, a nonsymbolic Gnostic Mass, that beautiful, evocative, erotic and esoteric ritual written and published by Crowley in the Equinox, after attending a Russian Orthodox Mass in the early part of this century. The Gnostic Mass has had far-reaching influence, and it would appear that the Wiccan Third Degree is one of the most blatant examples of that influence.

The Priest. O secret of secrets that art hidden in the being of all that lives, not Thee do we adore, for that which adoreth is also Thou. Thou art That, and That am I. I am the flame that burns in every heart of man, and in the core of every star. I am Life, and the giver of Life; yet therefore is the knowledge of me the knowledge of death. I am alone; there is no God where I am.
I presently have in my possession Gardner's certificate of license to organize said OTO camp, signed and sealed by Aleister Crowley.

Almost from the minute he placed it in front of me, things began to make some kind of sense. Clearly, this was Ye Book of Ye Art Magical. Just as clearly, it was an unusual piece, written largely in the same hand as the Charter I had obtained earlier -- that is, in the hand of Gerald Gardner. Of this I became certain, because I had handwriting samples of Gardner, Valiente and Crowley in my possession.
Crowley referred to Dr. Gardner and his OTO encampment in private correspondence almost to the time of his death, and spoke of it with optimism and enthusiasm.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant to understanding the true historical origins and development of modern Wicca, particularly its Gardnerian form. It critically challenges prevalent myths of ancient lineage, instead firmly situating Wicca within the 20th-century Western esoteric revival, highlighting the profound and often understated influence of Aleister Crowley's Thelema and the Ordo Templi Orientis. By providing a revisionist history, it offers a crucial, nuanced perspective essential for academic and practical study of Neopaganism and occult traditions.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes academics, researchers, and serious practitioners of Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Magic, particularly those specializing in the history of Wicca, Thelema, and the OTO. It also appeals to Wiccans and Neopagans who are open to a critical, evidence-based re-examination of their tradition's foundational narratives.
